OpenturnsPythonFunctionWrapper¶

class spsa.OpenturnsPythonFunctionWrapper(*args)¶

Wrapper for python functions that take as an argument stochastic fields, as well as scalar probabilistic distributions. The wrapper creates an interface to a new function, that only takes in scalar values, by decomposing the stochastic processes using Karhunen-Loeve

Parameters
functionSample: python function

function taking as an input random fields and scalars, specialy optimized for batch processing

functionSolo: python function

same function than above, but only working with one sample at once

processesDistributions: list

list of distributions and processes (processes are defined with the StochasticProcessConstructor)

outputDict: dict

dictionary containing data about the outputs of the function. The dimension as well as the output position has to be indicated

Notes

This class is used internaly by the StochasticProcessSensitivityAnalysis class, so the order of decomposition of the Processes hs not to be known and all is tracked internaly relatively robustly.

Methods

__call__(X)

Call self as a function.

composeFromProcessAndDistribution(…[, ntemp])

Using a list of ordered openturns distributions and custom defined Process with the StochasticProcessConstructor class we construct a vector of scalar distributions, according to the distributions and the Karhunen-Loeve decomposition of the processes.

getInputDescription()

Input description accessor.

getInputDimension()

Input dimension accessor.

getInputVariablesName()

Get the name of the input variables and fields

getKLDecompositionVarNames()

function to retrieve new set of variable names, once the function is depending on the KL decomposition

getOutputDescription()

Output description accessor.

getOutputDimension()

Output dimension accessor.

getTotalOutputDimension()

As we don’t know how many output variables the function returns, and the dimension of each of theme, we analyse it again

liftFieldFromKLDistribution(…)

Function to transform an 2D array of random variables (as we have allways more than one sample) into a collection of random variables and fields, according to the Karhunen-Loeve decomposition

matrixToOutputList(matrix)

Tranform the flattened image of the output back into it’s original shape

outputListToMatrix(outputList)

Flattens a list of ndarrays, sharing the same first dimension

setInputDescription(descIn)

Input description accessor.

setOutputDescription(descOut)

Output description accessor.

getOutputVariablesName
composeFromProcessAndDistribution(processesDistributions: list, ntemp: int = 1750)¶

Using a list of ordered openturns distributions and custom defined Process with the StochasticProcessConstructor class we construct a vector of scalar distributions, according to the distributions and the Karhunen-Loeve decomposition of the processes.

Parameters
processesDistributions: list

list of probabilistic distributions as well as Processes

Returns
composedDistribution: openturns.ComposedDistribution

random vector of various probabilistic distributions, in the order of the input list and with Processes decomposed as random variables

getInputVariablesName()¶

Get the name of the input variables and fields

getKLDecompositionVarNames()¶

function to retrieve new set of variable names, once the function is depending on the KL decomposition

getTotalOutputDimension()¶

As we don’t know how many output variables the function returns, and the dimension of each of theme, we analyse it again

liftFieldFromKLDistribution(KLComposedDistribution)¶

Function to transform an 2D array of random variables (as we have allways more than one sample) into a collection of random variables and fields, according to the Karhunen-Loeve decomposition

matrixToOutputList(matrix)¶

Tranform the flattened image of the output back into it’s original shape

outputListToMatrix(outputList)¶

Flattens a list of ndarrays, sharing the same first dimension
